w:r.w:t: will be able to recognize numbers 1-5 and will be able to count various objects up to five. Knowing how to count
They will also be able to write number and word form up to 5.

-branded opener slide that the teacher will display as the student enters the classroom.
Greet your student and introduce the lesson concept: Today, we are going to
learn how to count from one to five: 1,2,3,4,5
Students will count on their own or repeat after the teacher
Hold up fingers to signify each number
Time limit: One minute for a quick check
to determine how much extension should be used with the lesson.
Student will write one in number and word form.
Visual cue: Show various items and say one.
TPR: Use hands to point toward the student for you and then hand above the eyes for see in: “How many apples do you see?”
Visual cue: use real apples or pictures of apples to show

word form. Have student write both on the screen.
Say two- have student repeat the word several times.
Show various items in groups of two.
TPR: hold up two fingers to show two saying: “This is the number two.”
TPR: Use hands to point toward the student for you and then hand above the eyes for see in: “How many bananas do you see?”
Visual cue: use real bananas or pictures of bananas.

cue: Show a whiteboard to illustrate how to match by drawing a line.

Items in groups of 1, 2, 3 (Could be fruit, toys, or animals).
Circle a group of items on the screen and ask: “How many?”
Depending on level students may respond by naming the items.
Show various items in groups of four allowing the student to repeat the word four.
TPR: hold up four fingers to show four saying: “This is the number four.”
TPR: Use hands to point toward the student for you and then hand above the eyes for see in: “How many pineapples do you see?”
Visual cue: Use pictures or stickers of pineapples.
Write 4 in number form and in word form. Have the student write both on the screen.
Student draws a line from the number 1 to one banana to the word one.
cue: Show a whiteboard to illustrate how to match by drawing a line.
Show the previous slide with similar activity to show that you will be doing the same exercise (slide #6)
TPR: “What do you see?” By motioning toward you and see by putting your hand above your eyes.
Student will write five in number form (5) and word form (five).
Show various items in groups of four allowing the student to repeat the word five.
TPR: hold up four fingers to show five saying: “This is the number five.”
TPR: Use hands to point toward the student for you and then hand above the eyes for see in: “How many watermelons do you see?”
Visual cue: Use pictures or stickers of watermelons.
Write 5 in number form and in word form. Have the student write both on the screen.
“It is one, two, three, four, or five.”
up number cards out of order and ask: “What number is it?”
Hold up fingers and quiz student.
Show a white board with magnets or simple drawings and circle asking “How many?”
Student will draw lines to match word and number form.
Model drawing a line to match word and number forms.
If student does not say “This is____.” On their own say it first by circling 1 and having them repeat.

Student will write the number form next to the word form
Student will write each of the number form numbers and say it aloud during or after writing.
Circle each number and ask: “What is this?”
Have student practice writing each number several times.

Count items and write correct number underneath.
student should count out loud and write the appropriate number underneath the grouping.
